title: Bluetooth Speaker Comparison -- 2017 Edition
body:
I was in need of a new portable speaker, and like many of you, I was a little overwhelmed after doing an Amazon search and finding literally tens of thousands of options to choose from.  It's especially frustrating because probably the most important part of the product -- how good it sounds -- is not something you can really evaluate until after you physically have it.  So I picked four speakers to compare: Cambridge Soundworks OontZ Angle 3 Plus, Anker SoundCore Sport XL, Geek Beats Jolt5, and the JBL Flip 4.First, the 
Cambridge SoundWorks OontZ Angle 3 PLUS Bluetooth Speaker with 30-Hour Playtime - Richer Bass Greater Sound Quality & 10W+ Loud Volume, Water Resistant Splashproof, Portable Wireless Speaker
, is a slightly larger version of the best-selling speaker on Amazon with over 17,000 reviews and a $30 price tag, and this only costs $5 more, so why not give it a shot?  I chose 
Anker SoundCore Sport XL Outdoor Portable Bluetooth Speaker - 16W Output and 2 Subwoofers, IP67 Waterproof & Dustproof, Shockproof, 66ft Bluetooth Range, 15H Playtime, Built-in Mic, USB Charging Port
, partially because I have other Anker products that I'm pretty happy with, but also because the 66-foot advertised range seemed like it could come in handy if I were working in the backyard with my phone in my pocket and the speaker sitting on the porch.  I selected the 
GEEK BEATS JOLT5 10W X-Bass Wireless Portable Bluetooth Speaker and USB Power Bank - Green. IP65 Water and Dust Resistant with 5200mAh Samsung Battery.
 because it's the same price as the Anker, it has an average of 4.9 stars (wow!), and it can be used as a battery to charge your phone.  And finally, I chose the 
JBL Flip 4 Waterproof Portable Bluetooth Speaker (Black)
 because in my search, I kept seeing the JBL Flip 3 pop up in reviews for other speakers, and this is the newest (and supposedly slightly better) version of that speaker.Sound Comparison:  Sitting in my living room and swapping around between the four options, it's clear that the Flip 4 is the most, well, clear.  Considering it's also the most expensive, I kinda expected that to be the result.  Surprisingly, the OontZ was a solid second place with a bit more rumble in its bass compared to the Flip 4 but at the cost of less clarity.  The Anker and Jolt5 were noticeably flatter in their sound, seeming to favor the lows instead of an overall range, and this caused some distortion at higher volumes.  When I took the speakers outside, it's a slightly different story.  With the speakers on the patio, I walked into the yard about 25 feet and compared the sound quality again, and again I'd put the Flip 4 in the top spot.  This time, however, I'd actually say the Anker was a solid number 2.  At this distance, the distortion from having the volume up the whole way was not very noticeable and didn't detract from the music I was playing, and the Anker is a bit louder than the OontZ.  The Jolt5 is a distant last place being not only flat but also not as loud.  It's comparable to listening to the radio on a boombox from the 90s.Bluetooth Range:  With the speakers inside, all four started cutting in and out around the same spot about 30 feet away.  It's around a corner, so having a wall in the way seems to even the odds here.  Having an open space outside didn't seem to make a difference to the Jolt5, though, as it still broke up around 30 feet.  The product page on Amazon says 33 feet, so that's pretty accurate.  The OontZ fared a bit better and almost made it to the back gate about 60 feet away.  The Anker is pretty spot on with its advertised 66-foot range as it went a bit further than the OontZ, even onto the other side of the gate and almost into the road.  The Flip 4 was still going strong when I got to the other side of the road and couldn't go any further in a straight line, maybe 75 feet.Other Things:  Depending on what exactly you plan on using your speaker for, and just for comparison's sake, there are some differences that may be worth note:-- All four speakers come with a mini-USB to USB charging cable but not the plug.  If you've charged a cell phone in the last 10 years or so, however, you should probably already have one.-- The Jolt5 and OontZ come with a 3.5mm cable so you can plug your phone right into it instead of using bluetooth (though all four speakers have this option, just not the cable).-- The Anker and Jolt5 have a USB port so they can be used as a portable battery to charge your phone.-- The Anker, Flip 4, and Jolt5 have hand straps.  The OontZ does not come with one nor have a place to attach one.-- The Anker, Flip 4, and Jolt5 have audible cues when they power on or off.  The OontZ is silent.  All four speakers do, however, make a noise when you successfully pair a device through bluetooth.-- All four speakers are splash resistant, but only the Anker and Flip 4 are likely to live if they fall into the water (submersible up to 30 minutes)-- The Anker and Jolt5 are shock resistant, so they likely won't shatter if you drop them-- The OontZ has the longest battery life (30 hours) and the Flip 4 has the shortest (12 hours)-- The Flip 4 can be paired with other Flip 4's (through an app) to provide a wireless multi-speaker experience.  There are Bluetooth adapters that would allow you to do this with the other speakers if you wanted, as well as physically connecting them with 3.5mm cables.-- The Flip 4 comes in a variety of colors.-- They are all roughly the same size, just differently shaped (see pics)Conclusion:  The best bang for your buck is the OontZ Angle 3 Plus.  It's a measly $35 and sounds almost as good as the $100 Flip 4, especially inside.  In addition to being inexpensive, you can literally keep it blaring music for an entire day.  It's not quite as loud outside as the Anker or Flip 4, but it's also half the price.  If you're willing to pay for premium sound, go with the Flip 4 or even the Flip 3 if you want to save 20 bucks.  Supposedly the sound is comparable, just the Flip 4 has a longer playtime.  It really is noticeably clearer compared to the other options, so if you were using it with a projector to watch a movie, for example, the rumbling and distortion aren't going to drown out the dialogue, and likewise vocals on a music track don't get lost in the rest of the noise.  If you're planning on a bunch of outside activities, like mountain biking or camping, the ruggedness of the Anker and ability for it to charge your phone makes it your best bet.  I didn't do a drop test with any of these, but the Anker feels like a rubberized brick and would probably survive a fall.  Other than battery life, there's no reason to ever choose the Jolt5 over the Anker, especially considering they are the same price.  The Jolt5 is just worse in every way, and I honestly don't understand its 4.9 rating.The Jolt5 is going back.  The Flip 4 is staying.  I'm still debating between the Anker and OontZ and may keep them both since the cost combined is still less than a Flip 4.EDIT:  After further testing, the Anker is going back and I'm keeping the OontZ.  When plugged in with a 3.5mm cable, the sound is dramatically better with way more bass and a louder volume.  And it's still somehow the cheapest one.TL;DR:-- On a budget?  Cambridge SoundWorks OontZ Angle 3 Plus-- Best sound?  JBL Flip 4 (though I do wish it had a bit more bass)-- Most likely to survive your abuse?  Anker SoundCore Sport XL

title: Wireless/ portable  Great Sound
body: I have loved this little speaker ever since I bought it.  I am hearing impaired.  This little guy let me hear my you tube music list while in the shower.  My only gripe is the battery started to lose charge with in a month after the warranty expired in 2022.  I will probably buy another one.  I originally had a cheap speaker and only paid like $39.  It died within a few months.  I think JBL could figure out a way for us to replace the battery.  I purchased it 2020.  So I guess 2 years is the life of the battery.  It still sounds awesome.  I just have to plug it in after about an hour time.

title: Big sound for a little speaker
body: Very good sound quality, and good bass for such a small speaker.  Seems durable and well constructed.  Battery life is good, lasts a few hours if used continuously so it's good to plug in if you're using it for long stretches.  Comes with a usb charging cable, so to plug it in you'll need one of those little usb plug cubes.  Overall though very happy with this speaker, good value for the money.

title: Versatile, good sound, works very well as a speakerphone for conference calls
body: Bought this as a speakerphone system for conference calls. Having tried other systems I did not have high hopes, but this system works surprisingly well for conference calls.  I've asked others in the meeting regarding voice quality and have been assured that it is clear aside from a "change in timbre" from my headset.The music quality is a bit too boomy for my liking and too tinny if I turn bass boost off, but is good for a small speaker.Voice conferencing quality has the same boominess issue which can cause certain voices to be hard to hear.  In such situations I find that instead of turning bass boost off (which doesn't help much) just facing the speakers downwards helps.

title: Concert quality sound
body: I was introduced to this speaker when my son visited over the Christmas holiday. He propped it up on the window sill in the kitchen and tuned into some Christmas music. It was a nice addition to the overall holiday ambiance. Being a huge NFL fan, I bought this speaker primarily to listen SiriusXM football coverage on channel 88. But if I'm in relaxation mode, reading a book, or working on a project, l will call up some of my favorite music and play it in the background. I still can't believe the sound quality from such a compact speaker. Great range from booming bass to the highest notes of orchestral string instruments.

title: Great little Bluetooth speaker
body: It's remarkable powerful for its size, and the battery lasts for quite a few hours.  I haven't timed it, but I use it every day for a couple of hours and I've only had to charge it about once a week.  My only complaint is that the smartphone app doesn't offer an equalizer function.  It may be available on more expensive models, but this one doesn't have it and it would be useful.  Still, at this price, it's a great product.

title: There's a reason it's the baseline

title: Almost perfect speaker that punches above its class (been using it almost daily for over a year now)
body: I've been using it almost daily for 20 minutes to 2 hours for almost 1 1/2 years now.SOUND: It sounds almost as good as a full blown stereo system, if not better depending on the stereo. The only thing that makes an actual stereo a little better is the fact the speakers aren't combined into one unit and the sound comes from multiple directions (but I'm tempted to get a 2nd one to fix that).The sub-woofers on the sides of this pack a significant punch at medium to high volumes, but still improve the sound even at low volumes. The sound is very full and never sounds "tinny" or even flat like smaller speakers usually do.It's stereo. I feel like I shouldn't have to mention this, but I do because the newer one isn't...BUILD QUALITY: The build quality is outstanding with almost no wear and tear even after a year of daily use and moving it around semi-frequently. The only real wear is a two or three hairline scratches where I slide it in and out of multiple times a day and honestly the fact it remained that way and isn't all scuffed up like I expected is amazing.The charging port door doesn't seem like it'll wear out anytime soon, nor do the jacks seem worn at all. I swing the thing by its carrying cord all the time and haven't seen any scratching or wear as a result and I have full confidence nothing bad will happen from doing so.BATTERY: The battery life for me was about 2 weeks when I got it and now it's down to 1 to 1/2 weeks, but I think I've been listening at higher volumes more recently and considering how quickly laptop batteries lose their charge, I think it's held up very well.CONS: There are a couple of bad things I've noticed. First of all, the highs are a little too high for my liking and its the kind of thing you really won't notice unless you listen to it all the time, especially at higher volumes. I solved this using the EQ on Spotify. Furthermore, while the bass sounds good by default I know it can do more, so I set the EQ accordingly. The other thing is really quiet songs at higher volumes reveal a really soft background static from the internal amplifier. This flaw is more than likely inherent to non-grounded amplifiers or ones without room for extra circuitry that can minimize it (but it seems pretty minimal already, so don't worry about this). To be honest, I thought the speaker was so perfect I was surprised it had any flaws.PHYSICAL DEVICE: It's waterproof and I've taken it to dusty and dirty places and washed it off just fine. The water can muffle the sound if it gets stuck on the speakers, but I've been able to shake it off half the time.It's pretty small in person, about the size of a 16oz water bottle and fits almost everywhere water bottles do which is very convenient for taking it everywhere. Compared to similar speakers it's smaller and sounds better.BLUETOOTH: It can handles 2 simultaneous phone connections and trade between them seamlessly whenever the other person starts to play something. I've had issues with 3+ people, but they had iPhones and I think that was the problem because I think I've done 3 Androids before without problems (but iPhones still work well up to 2 devices). Furthermore, the auto-connect only works when it's set for both headset and music, but since I don't enable headset I have to manually connect each time (but I think this is just my phone as other peoples usually auto-connect).Overall, I think this speaker is amazing, better than the older and newer ones, and much better than its competitors. I paid about $85 for this and think it was absolutely worth it, but it's cheaper now and I'm happy it's still available since I think it really is the best you can get for this category.(side note: the pictures are from when I got it, but it's looks almost the same but with the 2 or 3 tiny scratches where I slide it every day)

title: Amazing Little Speaker! Get multiple!
body: I've had these for about 2 1/2 months....and all I can say is....Wow!! These are so much better than I expected!I bought 2 for stereo sound and they are astounding! I love them!!SOUND QUALITY:Fantastic!  It is amazing that sound this good comes from such small speakers. Great bass too.They make my ears happy...and the cost of them made my wallet happy too!! Win-win!LOUDNESS:I compared 2 different brand bluetooth speakers in a gym 72ft x 40ft.  I couldn't even hear the 1st test speaker. Then I tried the 2nd brand speaker JBL FLIP 4 and had no difficulty hearing it anywhere in the gym.  I then connected two JBL FLIP 4 speakers and the sound was amazing and it filled the gym.You can easily entertain with background music with these speakers.PHONE CONNECTIVITY:I wasn't planning on testing this feature. I didn't think I would use it and there was one review that said it didn't work that well anyway. Well fast forward, I had my phone connected to this speaker and was listening to music while showering and the phone & speaker started ringing. I pushed what I thought was the ignore phone call button on the speaker only to be met with silence from the speaker. I thought what is going on? I then thought let me say hello just to make sure I didnt answer the call. I said Hello and immediately was greeted by someone calling me on business. That was awkward and a little embarrassing. I apologized that I was in the shower. But did ask them if they could hear me okay. They said they could hear me just fine. So, I asked if I could call them back and a better time. So I guess that review saying it didnt work well was wrong. HahaBATTERY LIFE:I usually have my two JBL 4s bluetooth connected to each other AND my music device PLUS i have the speakers turned ALL THE WAY UP...and the battery life is good but not as good as I had read. I'm probably getting 7 hours +/- out of each one before I have to recharge them both.  But they recharge quickly and sound amazing!!PRODUCT QUALITY:The JBL Flip 4 feels really well made, not cheap in any way nor does it look or feel like they cut any corners when making it. It is sturdy and seems like it should last a long time.JBL CONNECT:Starting with the JBL FLIP 4 there is a new feature where other JBL FLIP 4's and newer JBL bluetooth speakers can connect to each other. You can connect up to 100 JBL speakers together for an incredible array of sound.COMPARISON WITH OTHER SPEAKERS:I watched a number of excellent bluetooth speaker reviews and read review articles before finally purchasing these speakers. I really enjoyed 2 YouTuber's video reviews, Oleg's Gadgets and JimsReviewRoom. The best review was on Oleg's Gagets Youtube Channel who played each speaker reviewed with the same song at the same volume level. He did a brilliant job!! You have to listen to his video review with headphones on to get the best sound quality and his audio recording of the speakers was SO GOOD that while he was off screen and walking across his hardwood floor to his couch, I whipped my head around because I thought someone was walking up behind me. I had to double check to make sure it was sound coming from his review and not my house. Lol.Enjoy hours of listening to these speakers!God bless!

title: Stop searching - 95% perfect speaker
body: This summer I needed a new BT speaker and I tried a bunch of them in this size range and this one is by far my favorite.  It's about 95% perfect, which is about 50% better than all the others I tried.  It sounds AMAZING - it's among the loudest of the bunch, and it definitely has some of the best bass of them all thanks to the TWO side-mounted bass radiators.  It sounds better than all of the cheaper models, as well as better than most of the more expensive models.  Probably the SONOS and Bose Soundlink Mini sound better, but they are considerably more expensive and are not waterproof.  That's the thing - the FLIP 4 checks pretty much every box except two, which are relatively minor flaws.  I wanted something rugged, with a decent battery, good controls, great sound, and that was not too bulky.  Probably what we are all looking for.PROS:Form factor - the beer-can size and shape is the best for carrying around.  The attached lanyard makes it even better, as you can hang it or swing it.Sound - incredibly rich, best-in-class bass, and great definition all around.  Gets loud, too.Build quality - this thing is waterproof and dustproof, and feels pretty indestructibeBT controls/features - easy-to-use buttons control volume, music, and speakerphone, as well as letting you link multiple JBL speakers.  Newest BT version (4.2)Battery - lasts all day, supposedly 12 hours, but varies by usage - and I've yet to have a problemCONS:No REW/Previous track.  This is what bothers me the most, I just don't understand why this isn't implemented somewhere.Directional, rather than 360-degree sound.  Not sure if I care.Other speakers I compared this to were the Marley Chant, two different iHome speakers, an old Bose Soundlink Mini, a Philips Shoqbox, something by OutdoorTech, a Magnavox speaker, and the UE Boom2.  I also spent way too much time researching other models online.  All of them had more shortcoming than this one - most just sounded worse or were underpowered, many were not waterproof or had lousy batteries, or no music controls.  Only a few let you link multiple speakers together.The speaker I bought first was the UE BOOM 2, because it gets the best reviews.  It costs at least $50 more than this and does not sound as clear.  It is a little more stylish I guess, and has a similar app to the JBL and is well supported by firmware and software updates.  However, it uses a stupid "tap" system to pause and FF (also no REW) that rarely worked.  The JBL has nice big buttons that work great.  Dedicated volume buttons control speaker/source volume, and double-pressing the play button skips a track.  I would LOVE a REW feature, a triple tap would do it, but I can ultimately live without it.  Ultimately, the UE BOOM 2 was not worth the extra money - it sounded worse in most situations (it was possibly louder and has 360-degree sound), and was infuriating to control.None of the cheaper speakers sounded better than this.  There was one, the MagicBox I think, that was louder than all of them and has awesome buttons for volume and music, but it's not waterproof at all.  The Fugoo looks amazing but it is only 6 Watts total, which is never going to be loud enough for anything other than a personal speaker.There are bigger speakers out there that have additional features like external charging and last for 24 hours at a time and pump out considerably more decibels, but they are also too big to fit my needs.  Honestly this one is nearly perfect, and maybe they can add REW in the future via an update and get it 100% right.

body: Update July 11 2020I haven't even used this speaker up until recently. The battery is only lasting about 4 hrs. I bought my son one before I bought mine and his last about 12 hrs. He uses his a lot. I'm really bummed out and I paid more for mine than I did his. Bought from this same place.Update June 25,2019:You are suppose to be able  To connect up to a 100 speakers with the JBL connect app.  My son is here and I tried connecting both of them and it doesn't work it just keep spinning and says discovering. They are both connected to Bluetooth in my phone. But it won't even pick up just one speaker. Any suggestions?I just recieved this today. So this is an out of box review. I will update later on batterie life and usage durability Etc.I bought this for my son for Christmas. Tried it out and I'm very impressed! It paired up quickly and easily to my phone. I played music through my samsung music app. Most music apps have a equalizer in them so you can make adjustments on the bass and treble. So those that have concerns... problem solved. The sound was pretty loud for such a small speaker.  I like that you can pair up more than one speaker. Because you can set the speakers in different rooms of the house and have music in every room and not have to worry about hearing it just from one speaker.I live in a small two-bedroom condo now so I had to take down my Mackie SRM 450 speakers and my equipment. I own a karaoke and DJ business. I have a really nice Bose SoundDock that I've been using for just everyday listening but it's heavy and bigger to take over to the pool. It's not waterproof and you can't hook up more speakers. This JBL Flip 4 is lightweight compact you can take it over to the pool and not have to worry about it getting wet because it's waterproof. I have not been able to test that but I have seen other reviews where that has been tested and they do prove to be waterproof. You can take it anywhere. It will fit in your purse.Bluetooth is probably the best technology that's ever come out. No more wires or cables.  And I can play the music that's on my phone and walk anywhere around the house I want with my phone or tablet because I'm not connected to the speaker. For the money this was a fantastic deal and well worth it. I've always been a fan of JBL speakers for centuries. I think they really outdid themselves with this. Now I want to buy some for myself. I also bought him a hard shelled carrying case for the speaker and his accessories the USB cable and the plug. The plug does not come with it but if you own a smartphone you probably already have one. And you can also buy just a plug. You could possibley use a USB charging cable in your car as well.

title: Worse sound quality than the JBL Flip 3? How?
body: I had a JBL Flip 2 and loved it, so I bought a JBL Flip 3 and also loved it! I also have friends who own the JBL Charge and the JBL Pulse, and I've always been impressed by those models as well. So, when the JBL Flip 4 came out, and I saw its price is so affordable, I went ahead and bought it because it never hurts to have a few (one in my office, one in the RV, one in the living room, etc).I bought the Ocean Blue color, which I was impressed with as soon as I opened it. The color is beautiful; dark, deep, and unassuming, but also different and unique. I really love the color. My first impression was that the Flip 4 felt heavier than my Flip 3, and I was excited to hear the quality of the sound, because I was sure JBL was continuing to innovate and improve their flagship bluetooth speaker...But I was stunned. When I first started a song, it would sound great. That's because the beginning of most songs are very "thin", meaning there's only a few things going on at a time, allowing the speaker to dedicate its full capacity to the one or two sounds happening. But when the song became "busy", meaning there were more layers, the audio became muddy, the bass went away completely, and the clarity I love so much about my Flip 3 isn't there at all.The song I first noticed it on is "Happy Pills", by Paul Leonard-Morgan (from the "Limitless" movie soundtrack). The song sounds great on the Flip 4 for the first 55 seconds, but the clarity and bass drops noticeably at the 1-minute mark (when additional sounds are added), and drops noticeably again at 1:15 when the song really hits its stride. Listening to this song on the JBL Flip 3 sounds great, but listening to it on my new Flip 4 is beyond disappointing.How did the sound quality decline with the newer model? The newer model should have improved sound quality, isn't that the reason you release a newer model? If not for improved sound quality, then the sound quality should at least remain the same but the device have improved battery life or bluetooth connectivity, right?Unfortunately I have to report that while the battery life may have improved, the improvement is marginal, and not worth it at all if that's the tradeoff for sound quality. The bluetooth connectivity seems to be the same as my Flip 3; I don't notice any difference at all.I started trying to use the JBL Connect app to play music on multiple Flip speakers at once, but I think that system has too many bugs and glitches in it that need to be fixed. I can't get it to work right for me, but I'll keep trying. If you're buying this SOLELY for the ability to link multiple speakers, you might want to look elsewhere until JBL improves this functionality substantially.I hope JBL releases an update for the JBL Flip 4 that will improve the audio quality, and I hope JBL fixes all the issues with the JBL Connect system. At this point, my faith in JBL and my love for their previous products is the only reason that I'm not returning this speaker.Note: I'm attempting to write more reviews on Amazon because I'm seeing more and more evidence of fake reviews on Amazon. I wish Amazon would do more to combat fake reviews. If you see a product on Amazon with over a thousand reviews and over 4.5 stars, please be wary and use sites like FakeSpot and/or ReviewMeta. No idea how accurate these fake review tools are, but I figure it can't hurt. Thanks for reading!

title: 10/10 For reasons, etc...
body: My Flip 3 died a slow and painful death, so I had to buy a new one. Deciding between the flip 4 and 5 wasn't too difficult. I'm a musician, so when I found out the Flip 5 played only in mono it was an instant deal-breaker.The Flip 4 is durable, waterproof, and very loud. I need to turn the volume down to just 3 clicks at work to keep it low enough so my boss can't hear it from his office. However, I blast it literally everywhere else I go. My car stereo is broken so I just set this thing on my dash and it powers through the noise of my open window going 80 up and down the HWY 101. I sing in the shower and it does a great job of overpowering my terrible voice, even when drenched in water, so that's a plus (I'm a drummer, not a singer). I also set it on my hood while washing my carblast week and the whole neighborhood could hear me blasting everything from metal to deep blues to K-pop. I'm just kidding, I don't listen to K-pop.The Bluetooth works well. Almost too well... I was in my car on my break and left the thing sitting on my desk. I was trying to watch a YouTube video of how to jailbreak an iPhone (idk why, I hate apple products) and I couldn't figure out why my audio wasn't working. I cranked my phone all the way up and still nothing. Turns out I left the Bluetooth on and my whole office's ears were bleeding from the blaring voice of Linus from "Linus Tech Tips".I recommended this speaker to my friend so she bought one, and linking them together is very useful. If you set two of them back to back in the middle of a room, the sound just fills the room completely, which I'm sure will be great for parties or social gatherings once we can have those again. (If you're reading this in the future and covid is finally been long over and you have no clue what I'm talking about, look it up, it's awful (yes, I'm bored (go look at newer speakers, there's probably a Flip 9 by now, jeez))).Anyways...10/10 Good Purchase

title: Love it! Just upgraded from the Flip 3
body: I have always been a JBL fan. I love the brand. So it's no surprise that I decided to upgrade to the Flip 4. Where to begin?First. The sound is great, for a portable speaker it really fills a room! My partner loves having it in the kitchen when he is washing the dishes, and I can hear the music through the house at a quality level (whether I want to or not ha!) I use it when I am in my studio painting, and can place it anywhere and still get great sound!Second. The color I picked is beautiful. Truly, the dark teal color is awesome! I always love darker colors since you can't see how dirty they are over time like lighter colors. It also helps me find it easier when I eventually always lose track of it. I can't help it, I lose things easily, but the color helps me find it right away!Third. Design. It feels more sleek and sturdy from the previous design of the Flip 3. I really love how they keep improving. The design sets the tone for the sound quality of this product. The charging port area is covered up but easy to access. Next to the charging port is an AUX connection for those that can't connect via Bluetooth. Connection to the device is easy as well, and always easy to pair new devices to it. The charging port is the same as my samsung phone charger so I can switch them out really easily if I misplace one or the other. (and like I said before, I misplace things easily)Fourth. JBL in general is awesome. They have MANY designs of speakers that ALL connect to each other!! How awesome is that?!??! When I get together with my family, we all bring our JBL speakers and connect them all to place around the house. That way we can play one song throughout the entire house. This keeps a party connected and going.Other random things about it. It's water resistant, so having it by the pool or at the beach during the summer is hassle free. The price is affordable, especially compared to most portable speakers with less reliability.Pros:-Sturdy-Reliable-Great color-Awesome Sound QualityCons:-Honestly, can't find any.

title: Best Speaker at This Price Point
body: Sound quality is so subjective I want to review other aspects of the speaker and in comparison with comparably priced Anker Sound Boost. The reason is I was leaning toward the JBL Flip 4 but was researching Amazon to see if there were better options.  There were a number of reviews for Anker that rated it superior to Flip 4, some from people professing to be experts or audiophiles. I took a chance and originally purchased the Anker, returned the next day and bought the Flip 4.  I don;t profess to be either an expert or audiophile but I've bought many Wireless Speakers ranging from cheap to Beats and Bose.  When I opened the Anker I was disappointed. The USB charging cable was obviously flimsy and cheap and the documentation even cheaper appearing. I had charge issues right off the bat and tried to contact support. In the interim I learned from web research that charging issues are not uncommon and that the manufacturer recommends using a different (higher quality) charging cable as the first remedy. I also learned that the instruction manual is incorrect and that the manufacturer is familiar with both problems yet continue to ship the speakers with these two inadequate components!  I did connect the Anker to a couple of my devices and the Bluetooth connection was quick and easy. Both the range and sound quality were less than I expected. And, when I connected to my High Resolution Sony Digital player the volume control of the player was disabled.  I researched that problem and found that it is a known issue when the Sony is connected to some lower quality Bluetooth devices.The JBL Flip 4 arrived professionally packaged (as expected) with a robust USB charging cable and separately packaged, professionally printed and ACCURATE instructions.  Initial charge was quick and as documented. Bluetooth connection is also quick and easy.  Range is probably at least as good as advertised and way better than the Anker. All controls of my connected devices (i.e. Sony player volume, etc.) work perfectly. Sound quality is subjective but that along with volume, bass, etc. it certainly meets my expectations and certainly is superior to Anker Sound Boost.  JBL and Harman Kardon are brands that music lovers know they can trust and they continue to deliver.  This is probably the best Bluetooth Speaker you can buy for under $100.  I only share this in case someone else is considering the Flip 4 and checking out the options.  Please don't get fooled by reviews of some competitors, especially those who use JBL Flip 4 in unfavorable comparison. Of course we all buy speakers for the sound not for the packaging or accessories or printed material but if those things are inferior it's pretty indicative of what to expect with the main product.

title: Little Package, Huge, Clear Sound!
body: PROSBIG SOUND: This little gizmo gives clean, clear sound across the entire frequency range, including plenty of bass. If you need volume, it will give you quite a bit, and if you run several together (see the JBL web site for specs and capabilities), you could greatly increase the coverage area. Several of these might make an excellent compact wireless speaker system, as long as you start with fully charged batteries and remember the power limitations of each unit - 16 watts (8 X 2) maximum.FEATURES -  Some of JBL's larger and smaller models don't have all of the features this one has, like audio input jack, speakerphone capability, etc., so those are nice plusses for this model.SO-SOsBATTERY LIFE: I have no idea if it will live up to JBL's claims as I just got it, but if it even comes close, I will be happy. If you use it near a USB power source, you can keep the USB cable plugged in and extend the life of the charge. I have this Flip 4 and also a GO 2, and neither came with a charger, but since the world is being overrun by USB chargers, that's probably a good thing. They each came with the USB cable.VULNERABILITY: Inside each end of the tube is a resonator that acts to enhance the low frequencies, and they do a good job, but they appear to be as compliant and delicate as exposed speaker cones. For that reason I wish the designers had included a protective grille over each end. I might try to make my own. Other than that, the case seems quite rugged.CONSOther than the Caution above, I haven't found any yet. A couple of minor things - it is a stereo system, but with the speakers so close together, the separation is hard to hear. However, it is definitely a more open sound than you would get if you were running both channels through one speaker. Also, the power button requires a stronger and more centered push than most, and at first I thought mine was defective.Yes, I would enthusiastically recommend this to anyone looking for a small wireless speaker system.

 Honestly, the price hits hard but combining it’s looks, sound quality, seamless bluetooth and battery life. It’s almost hard not to buy a JBL speaker for this price for on the go.First mentioning I got the camo edition but that does not change how the speaker works. Unlike the flip 3 stealth.Sound quality is precise. It hits hard on bass, not too much but enough to leave plenty of room for the lows, mids, and the highs which is exactly how it should be. Distortion is little to none, and most occurs on songs with already distorted sounds that just don’t take advantage of what JBL does best.Bluetooth is seamless like mentioned, you push the power, it go’s to pairing than you link up and your set! Although, if you plan on using the party feature, while charging your speaker it wouldn’t be a bad idea to download the app and update the speaker as it’s most likely outdated like mine was.Than battery life. I’ve seen coworkers go days on a single charge but that’s with on off use. Daily use it can handle quite a punch, almost 6 hours on a full charge if I remember correctly, probably more if your really hammering it.The party-mode feature needs some work, it’s range from speaker to speaker is very limited. I would range it to no more than 8ft approximately. It also drops signal occasionally with the paired speaker for party-mode and picks back up even within range. But still needs refinementThe video I posted does not sound well as it has to run through my phone. Although their is plenty of audiophile reviews out there that demonstrate the Flip4’s ability.Thanks for reading my review!

title: Good speaker, JBL app is a bit wonky
body: Sounds good with enough bass for its' size.  The bass is just average - mixes well with mid/highs but won't impress most.  It's loud enough for most listening activities, but not for that great song you just want to crank it up.I bought 2 JBL Flip 4's for proper stereo sound (left-only on the left speaker, right-only on the right speaker).  The Party button/mode is no-brainer easy, but each speaker plays both L/R stereo channels which is annoying when you want true stereo.The JBL app is kinda wonky.  You have to stop any other music/apps or else it's super slow to discover the Flip 4 (if it ever does).  You have to wait until all speakers are truly discovered AND report the green battery-strength bar (up to 30 seconds).  If you're impatient it just won't work.  It's not intuitive that you only pair *1* primary speaker with Bluetooth, and rely on the party-mode button for this primary speaker to connect to the other.The app is the only way to get 2 speakers into true stereo mode, but if you do much of anything else on your phone it "forgets" and the speakers switch back to party mode.  Also when your music app starts a new song, it first plays on the primary speaker then takes ~5 seconds to start playing on the secondary.  On movie night I use 1/8" cables and a special L/R splitter because I can't rely on the app+bluetooth.So, minus 1/2 star for the volume/bass, and another 1/2 star for the lame app.

title: Great quality and sound at a good price!
body: I have enjoyed this speaker! First the Pros:- Sound quality is great with nice bass for its size- Very durable and water resistance is great- Battery life is quite good- Portability.. You can take it almost anywhere easily- JBL connect is easy and a great featureThe cons (if you want to call them that):- Although sound quality is great, it starts to suffer at higher volumes, loss of bass and a bit of distortion- Not quite as loud as I would have liked. I use this on my Side X Side and most of the time it sounds just fine but when really revving at high speed it gets drowned out by engine noise. Most trail riding, however, it performs well. Adding a second speaker with JBL connect has helped drastically.  I have used these speakers on a regular basis and have to say I love them. On the porch, around a fire, camping, traveling, etc. Having the ability to connect several of these and spread them out over a large area makes for great flexibility. Just two of them in my large yard allows for lower volume with sound covering a large area that is easy to hear, as opposed to cranking just one speaker and having a "loud" area near the speaker where you can't have conversation. I have had them out riding, covered in dust and dirt, splashed with water, and seen globs of mud splashed on them. A damp cloth cleans them up nicely. I have dropped, kicked, and bobbled them all over without negative side effect. The connectivity range seems to be quite good, I have never had connectivity issues.  My opinion? You should buy this, and you will likely buy at least a second one like I did. Enjoy!

title: This speaker is great. I needed a 2 speaker setup for work ...
body: This speaker is great. I needed a 2 speaker setup for work and home use, where one would sit on my toolbox while a second would travel around in a service cart with me. I had considered MiniRig due to hifi sound quality, size, unlimited daisy chaining, great app options and dedicated subwoofer but ultimately the lack of play/pause/volume buttons on the speakers as well as price drove me away. I decided to try one of these, and just ordered a second now that I have checked sound quality. JBL told me if the speakers time out when connected (if you have media not playing for example), they will lose their link and you will have to reconnect them. I had trouble finding that information and had to call, so hopefully it helps someone else. JBL said they would implement this feature in the future where they would relink on power up, this would open up options of having full room wireless setups semi-permanently arranged, would not have to pick them all up and connect every time. I will chime back in here with comments once I've thoroughly tested using 2 of them at once, in and outside of work.Pros:-Can play and charge at the same time - unlimited runtime for parties if plugged into the wall. Should be loud enough to cover at least one room, but will be running at upper volume levels-Bluetooth 4.2 and Connect+, exclamation point logo indicating latest design language from JBL-Exterior is rugged, waterproof and has a wrist strap - no need for additional carrying bags or enclosures unless you want to preserve aesthetics-Much louder, more bass and better quality than the Clip 2Cons:-The 40mm drivers and passive radiators just don't make bass. That's okay, it's an unwinnable battle of physics in a speaker this small. They do kick enough to leave you with the impression that this little speaker has attitude. Adding an Xtreme 2 or boombox into the daisy chain would surely help with that-I can't think of any other cons. The sound quality is not particularly super high end or anything, but it does sound more than acceptable. It really is a fantastic looking speaker in person, particularly the passive radiators. The buttons are very nice and easy to press, unlike the Clip 2's recessed clickless buttons.

title: Great little speaker for a decent price.
body: I've got three of these. They can all be connected together to give a surround sound experience and they work best indoors, but actually carry well outdoors as well. A drawback to connecting the devices is range. Unfortunately, the range on these isn't really that great. So, for outdoor uses, it can be annoying when one speaker moves too far away and you have to reconnect manually if it's separated for too long. Indoors, you have to worry about walls and things that mess with signal strength. Even a single, hollow, basic door can interrupt the signal if you move more than 10 feet away from the signal transmitter.I particularly love the water resistance on these bad boys because I take mine kayaking all the time. I have, in fact, tested the submersibility of these and, although not recommended, they will not be harmed if only underwater for a few seconds. So, definitely don't worry if it starts raining, but it's still best to give them a little refuge from the constant barrage of water. Spalshing is fine, even mud is OK (again, not recommended...but it won;t break the thing) and you can wash it off if it gets dirty...Just don't go overboard- it's still a speaker.It's biggest drawback is the battery life. The louder it gets and the more bass you push, the shorter the battery life. I have had one of these for 2 years and it's still lasts for a good 6 hours on one full charge with continuous play at max volume.very easy to use and set-up.Overall, a fantastic speaker at a really decent price- the surround sound feature is an excellent selling point- although, I wish it was compatible with other JBL surround devices...stupid software changes (but that's a whole other issue)...Get it. It's worth it.

title: Loud and clear audio, easy connectivity, solid build.
body: I bought two of these a few yars ago and they are still going strong. There are whoofer speakers at each end for low bass output, and the main speakers are great. The sound is clear and fully covers bass to treble. This product will fill an 20x30 foot room with sound that can be cranked up to such loud sound people will be asking you to turn it down. Ran over 6 hours straight at a graduation party outside with excellent results. The units can be set up as a stereo pair. (Get one red the other white or black for easy setup). Very satisfied with this purchase. There is now a slightly bigger unit for just $10 more per unit, with an even bigger battery.Another nice feature is that you can BlueTooth pair or connect by an aux output from your computer, then you can extend the pairing to as many other of these units by pressing a second button that sets up pairing with as may JBL speakers as you want to spread around the house. That is in addition to the stereo setup that can done with an app that is loaded on your iPad or iPhone.This is a solid unit. The inputs are fully gasketed. Rubber bumpers at the ends. solid buttons that are waterproof. Great for the beach, great for travel. I haven't tried dropping, but I wouldn't worry if I did.The Flip 4 is great! But the Flip 5 should be even better! Higher output, bigger battery. Maybe even better bass since it is a little bigger.

title: You can do better, but it will cost you a LOT more.
body: Things I like:1. Bluetooth connectivity is fast and works every time.2. Sound quality is very good, very balanced with no over-emphasis on any area. If you are an audiophile, you know what I mean when I say it has a VERY flat response (a good thing).3. Bass gets surprisingly low if you know how to use a 5 band equalizer, but only sounds good that way with lower volumes..to be expected.4. Price is right on the money for value. It's what you would expect to pay for what you get.5. Fully waterproof and submersible.6. Mini USB is good for me as all my other devices still use it. Lack of USB-C not a negative for me.7. Love the 5 dot battery meter so I never run out of juice suddenly.8. Aux input is handy but I don't use it myself.9. Everything about this speaker feels rugged, hefty, reliable, user friendly, and stowable for travel.Things I don't like:1. My only complaint is that while it DOES have 2 drivers for true stereo sound, the stereo image is verynarrow and focused, making you put the speaker directly in front of you to truly appreciate the good audio. There is no "spatial" effect to be found here, but it's a small price to pay for all the positives. Its a great speaker to play when I have company at the dinner table.

title: a little emphasis on vocals
body: Been using it for about a month now and have had no problems with.  Here's my 2-cents worth review:It does get very loud for such a small speaker. I was really impressed with the amount of volume and punch coming out of this little thing.  It had no problems filling a med sized room with about 10-12 people. The battery life is amazing!  We kept it playing all night for a party and never had to charge it (the iPhone 6 battery crapped out well before the speaker's did).  The construction is solid and well engineered to take some abuse.  The option to Bluetooth chain several of these speakers together and configure two on them in left-right stereo mode is also a huge plus.With that aside, the main thing I hate about it is that there is some kind of processing going on where when you turn up the volume it creates a bump in the midrange frequencies that colors the sound a bit and places an exaggerated emphasis on vocals which I don't care for.  It's almost like a slight "center channel" effect.  If you like to hear very clear vocal tracks or dialog then this is the speaker for you.  There should be a switch to turn this processing off (music mode / video dialog mode) - or at least include this feature in the free "JBL connect" iphone app so you can control the speaker's sound EQ (music, video, dialog, podcast, etc).  My Yamaha soundbar has it, why can't the Flip 4 have it too.  The speaker's sound quality is decent as long as you are playing certain types of music through it.  I found it sounds a bit harsh and chopped when playing traditional jazz, classical, or world music through it at higher volumes - (the sound of a jazz drum kit, upright string bass, and a sax together sounded horrible at higher volumes).  At lower volumes it sounds more flat and natural. The speaker seems to be more suited for playing rock, dance music, R&B, pop, country, and video/DVD soundtracks.  Placing the speaker against a wall or flat object is definitely recommended and will help to bring out more bass and round out the sound a bit.As comparing it with a few other speakers I have tested the Flip 4 is definitely one of the best (and loudest) in it's price range.  I would give it 3.5 stars but I have to round it up to 4.

title: Returned an Oontz to buy this instead -- was the right decision
body: I initially tried to save some money and bought an Oontz (forget which model, it was about half the price, though, so this might not be comparing apples to apples) triangle-shaped speaker. It arrived, and honestly it sounded so horrible I assumed it must be defective and returned it.  I'm not really a sound snob, but that speaker sounded awful. Everything was distorted and mushy, even at medium volumes.So, after reading that basically everybody thought the JBL speakers sounded better, I decided to order this one. So far, I'm super happy.  What sounded distorted and mushy on the Oontz sounds clear and warm on the JBL, even at louder volumes. The JBL does sound the tiniest bit tinny or hollow, but that is just me being critical, it doesn't bother me at all.  Honestly I was surprised at how good the speaker sounded.As for volume, we had an older, cheaper Barricade speaker that we took to the tennis court, but unless we were right near the speaker, we couldn't enjoy the music (i.e. when we were both at opposite baselines of the court, neither of us could hear the music clearly).  With this speaker, even at half volume, the music is nice and clear on the court. I take it into the garage when I'm "working" on "projects" and it's more than beefy enough to fill the space even at lower volumes. We have ~600 sq foot living / dining room and I think 1 of these would be enough to comfortably listen in that space.Battery charge -- I haven't had this very long, but I've listened to it for about 8 hours so far and haven't yet needed to recharge. Can't really comment on that, other than I'm happy if I need to throw this on the charger once a week or so, which seems to be the case.

title: I'm a fan.
body: I went and compared 3 similar portable speakers with each other (same price of around $100 each):JBL Flip 4- Best quality sound of the 3 (amazing quality - very similar to Bose Soundlink Mini)- No noticeable crackle at max volume with high treble in music- Strongest/deepest bass (my table was shaking on max volume)- Very loud max volumeUltimate Ears WONDERBOOM- Smaller than JBL 4 but larger than Bose Micro- Crackling at max volume for some songs with high treble (Was not expecting this)- Bass is not as strong (very slight bass)- Very loud max volume (similar to JBL 4)Bose SoundLink Micro Bluetooth- Smallest of the 3- Max sound was at 75% that of JBL 4/Ultimate Ears- Sounds "muffled" and not clear (quality is not even close to that of Bose Soundlink Mini)- Exposed charging slot (is this really waterproof?)Overall - I would pick JBL (amazing quality & very similar to Bose Soundlink Mini, but waterproof!) and Ultimate Ears for portability (75 % size of JBL 4). title: Gotta spent to get quality sound
body: The concept of bluetooth speaker is usually small cheap with low quality sound.  As technologies advances premium speakers now comes with solid construction, large drivers and high power amplifiers.  For those who is in the market for a cheap speaker will find hundreds to choose from.  No matter how good the reviews are for the Tribet, Oontz and UE Booms they are all run of the mill speakers that only satisfies the masses.  For high quality sound buyers usually have to step up to a higher price point.  While higher end Bose, Sony and Harmon costs over $200, half of that will get you pretty decent sounding speakers.  The Flip 4 looks great and its easy to carry, rugged and waterproof.  With 10 hours of battery life this little speaker can pump out clear highs and satisfying lows.  Voice sound natural and bass drum comes with a kick.  There are numerous placement options for the speaker and all controls are intuitive and easy to reach.  The clean upper range produced is a good sign that the component speakers are of good quality.  Driving 8 watts X 2 along with 2 side firing bass radiators the speaker has enough power to fill a medium sized room.  Like most I have been in the market for a good sounding speaker and have been disappointed time after time.  Realizing that a cheaper speaker will simply not satisfy my needs, going up in pricing to get the Flip 4 was the best decision I made.  If sound quality, portability and all-weather construction is important to you then you should spend to get this.  At $90, this little gem is better than the Bose, Harmon and Sony counterparts.

title: Awesome sound for those who like to Rock!
body: I bought the JBL Flip 4 a year ago and I couldn't be happier with its performance!  After years of buying Jam Touch speakers and having them quit after a few months, I just moved on.  I like all types of music, but I'm a die hard classic rock fan.  I want good bass quality and no tinny sounds at all; that's too much treble folks. This speaker delivers exactly what I want and it seems to go for days on end without a charge.  Although I don't often play it at full volume, when I do there isn't a single rattle, reverb, or crackling issue to be heard.  I even had the neighbor complain the other day that it was too loud!  This coming from a 19 year old who plays music from speakers in his back yard all hours of the night!The pairing experience with this speaker is seamless.  It pairs instantly with my Samsung Note 20 Ultra, android tablet, and laptop.Today I'm ordering a second JBL Flip 4 to pair up with mine to kick up the stereo experience.  Keep in mind you can't pain the Flip 4 with the JBL Flip 5 due to the Flip 5's PartyBoost limitations!All in all this is a great little speaker for the money!  It's portable, stylish, and has a sound that can't be beat at this price!

title: Happy with Speaker. Great customer service from both amazon and JBL!
body: The JBL4 flip speaker i purchased a few weeks ago worked great with my Moto G7 phone. The bluetooth connected automatically when both were turned on to bluetooth. I purchased this for a dance exercise class at the beach. We all loved the sound and was able to hear the music and words clearly. However, it would not pair with my iphone7.Then, because I could not connect this speaker with my iphone7 I hit the "forget this device" link on the Moto G7 thinking this would help. It still did not connect to the iphone7 . iphone7 never located the speaker.Well, now I went back to the Moto G7 and it no longer would connect to the JBL4 flip speaker either.Then amazon customer service connected me directly with a JBL tech support when I called about my problem. JBL helped my Moto G7 reconnect with the JBL4 flip speaker with a few resets. But no luck with the iphone7. They stated that they have not been able to get the iphone7 specifically to connect and had been trying for a while. We got off the phone and I kept looking for the magic button and I found it. Privacy->Location Services->System Settings--> Network and Wireless and turn it on! Then I hit the bluetooth button to locate devices and the JBL4 was found by my iphone7!! So this was not the JBL speakers fault! It was how to make your iphone7 findable by the bluetooth device. YAY.

title: Don't try to use it with non-native Bluetooth TV
body: The sound quality was very good, in the limited testing I did.  My goal was to use these (I bought two) as additional speakers for my TV, or to use them instead of the TV's built-in speakers.  The TV is not natively Bluetooth-capable, so I bought a third-party Bluetooth transmitter (1Mii B03Lite), connected to my TV via optical (TOSLink) cable. I also wanted one speaker to provide LEFT channel only and the other speaker RIGHT channel only, for true stereo, rather than having each speaker provide both left AND right channels.  These speakers ARE able to do this, but only through use of the JBL Connect app on your phone or tablet.  I was concerned that the left/right separation would work ONLY while the phone was connected, which it normally wouldn't be in my scenario.  However, once turned on in the app, the left/right separation continued to work, even when the phone was off and the sound source was the Bluetooth transmitter connected to the TV.  The big problem -- and this might very well have been the fault of the transmitter, not the speakers -- was that there was a 1-2 second delay in the sound coming from the TV, so that the sound did not match up with lip movement.  That made the TV essentially unwatchable.  Because of this problem, I will need to return the speakers and the Bluetooth transmitter.  I will cross-post this review to the BT transmitter, as well, so that people know that it's the COMBINATION of the two that doesn't work as hoped.  The speakers themselves seem to work well, albeit in limited testing.

title: Wireless pairing is fantastic. Highly recommend these speakers
body: I bought four of these for a party I was hosting where we didn't have access to the built in speakers. I had a couple options, I have other bluetooth speakers, but I would only be able to connect one to my phone and play from one end of the room. The other option was bringing my bookshelf stereo system from 2004 to the party and spread the speakers out as far as the wires would allow but again it would only be on one side of the room so I would have had to blast both options in order for the other side of the room to hear it, thus making the people closer to the speakers hate me. SOO I found these and ordered four to try out in my situation. I connected one to my phone then the other three to the source speaker. I was able to put one speaker in each corner of the room and flawlessly stream spotify from my phone and have a nice volume level throughout the hall. I had numerous people ask me how I was playing music all over and I introduced them to the speakers. In fact my step father liked them so much he bought two of them from me (I had no need for four after that day anyway so it worked out for me) I have used the remaining two speakers numerous times since I bought them, most recently at the beach on my family vacation. I was able to leave my phone in the truck, stream music to both speakers and provide music amongst 5 pop up tents, the only struggle was finding the kind of music everyone enjoyed! :P

title: Best Speaker You Will Find At $100
body: Before anyone assumes that I received any sort of discount, I bought this at the full price of $99.95Price - As the title indicates, in my opinion this truly is the best speaker out there that you can buy with $100. At $99.95 this speaker is very affordable, of course if you live in most states you will pay about $7 more for tax but in certain states you won't be charged any. In the box you will receive a JBL Flip 4 speaker (with a paracord loop), a JBL tangle free Micro-USB cable, Quick Start Guide, Important Safety Instructions, and a Warranty Card.Build - The JBL Flip 4 is considered a rugged speaker and also because it is IPX7 waterproof, it can be immersed in water up to 1 meters (or roughly 3 feet) for up to half an hour. Just remember to disconnect all cables and close the rubber flap. Although this is a rugged speaker, I would try very hard not to drop this or physically damage it. The Flip 4 has a total of 6 buttons: Play/Pause/Skip Track/Google or Siri/Answer/End Call, Volume Up, Volume Down, Bluetooth, Power, and JBL Connect+ (Connect+ allows you to connect 100 or more Connect+ enabled speakers for a surround sound experience or to full bigger areas). The Flip 4 also has 2 ports and an opening for your paracord loop, the 2 ports under the rubber flap are for a 3.5mm AUX cable and a Micro-USB charging cable. There is also a built-in microphone for calls or voice commands using Google or Siri.Sound - I have few things to say about the sound quality of this speaker, simply because it is that amazing! The Flip 4 is unlike most speakers $100 and under. This speaker will not lose sound quality at max volume nor will it get distorted with bass heavy tracks. Even when under water, the sound will not suffer, it actually seems to increase your bass.I highly recommend this product and encourage anyone looking for a speaker around $100 to purchase the JBL Flip 4

title: Premium feeling & sounding speaker for a budget price!
body: (tldr at the bottom)Before I purchased this speaker I was using a UE Boom, most likely a first generation model. It was nice, and did what I needed it to. But it was getting old and the battery life was non-existent. So! I hopped on Amazon and found this speaker on sale, and I thought why not. When it came in I was very surprised at the overall quality. I've also had a Nose Mini SoundLink Gen 1, and I compare almost all portable speakers to that. This doesn't quite come close to the Bose, but that's okay! This isn't in the same category. For the price, you get an awesome, little speaker that kicks some nice bass (the sides move like a subwoofer!), it has a solid weight to it for a small speaker so it feels premium (which is important for some people), and the connection to your phone along with controlling the speaker is seamless. It has a little rope for attaching it to something, and a rubber cover for the charging port. I haven't tested the water resistance/proofness of the speaker, but it's fine so far after being in the bathroom when I shower!TLDR:If you're looking for a "budget" speaker that eminates a build quality similar to premium brands, and that produces quality sound comparable to the same brands, buy this speaker.Catch it on sale if you can for an extra boost, but if you're worried about this disappointing you at all... don't!

title: JBL Flip 4 Musing - My New #1
body: Although I'm not doing speaker reviews anymore I was so impressed by the JBL Flip 4 that I had to write a little something. The Xiaomi Mi has been my go-to BT speaker. It has really great sound; especially for the size. Sadly I accidentally played some frequency test tones at high volume and my Xiaomi Mi was blown. After 3 days of only having laptop speakers I was fed up. I needed something better. Good things have been written about the JBL Flip 3, and I always wanted to give it a try. Now the 4 is out and I hear it's even better! Being desperate for quality sound I bought one.I really wasn't planning on buying any speakers and really couldn't afford it. I'm experienced and very picky about audio. From all I've read my expectations were very high. Given all of this the odds were stacked high against the Flip 4.Once I heard the thing I was stunned at how full and well balanced it sounds! I have a thing for small speakers that sound big and this doesn't disappoint at all. Even better is that it manages to sound big without any lame DSP tainting the sound. There is no silly bass boost and no compression; just good full sound. This is my new #1.

title: The BEST speaker in it's price range.
body: This small buddy is doing all you would expect it to do and more. Seriously, great sound from such a small speaker.It can satisfy almost all your need (will write about it later)You need it for a small / medium house. Great, this is what you need. Despite the size, it can be really loud, and the best thing is that it still sound great at max vol, you can hear quality bass and everything.If you like to listen to music outside, take a speaker everywhere with you, you'll like it too. For all biking lovers - it perfectly fits in the bottle holder.And ever when it'll start to rain - hide the speaker from getting wet will be the last think you need to think about,  Flip 4 is COMPLETELY waterproof.If you like to listen to music in a shower (like I do), you'll like it too, you even can answer phones while in a shower ( well, that'll be a little weird).Another cool feature  - you can connect 2 devices to it at the same time. Do you have a friend that always wants to play HIS track on YOUR speaker? Now you both can stay connected and if you don't like the track you can stop it and play your's again (not a nice thing to do, but hey, but sometimes it's really helpful).You even can connect up to 100 devices to play at the same time, don't know who will do this, but I would like to see this.The only downside is that it doesn't float in the water ( if you like to listen to music underwater maybe you'll be ok with it). title: Not quite up to expectations for JBL.
body: I like JBL stuff. Really. But I gave this four out of five stars for a few reasons. First of all, I'm fully aware that this is a small speaker. Most of the reviews say that this flip4 is super. I think its merely good for what it is. Overall sound quality is good, but due to the small size, there's not alot of bass. Nice weight and feel to the speaker and the materials are top notch.  The sound doesnt really distort at full volume, but theres not much difference between about 70% to 100%. A little bonus is the lanyard attached to it. I added a carabiner clip so I can carry it anywhere. The waterproof design is great and the speaker feels very durable. However, when laid flat it tends to roll. JBL should have made the ends hexagonal so that it's immobile on flat surfaces. Nice to be able to listen to other media and take calls if needed on the phone. Also, the battery life sucks. I dont get more than 4 hours of playback before having to recharge. I've never tried to connect multiple speakers using the JBL connect feature, but maybe that's what makes these popular. I bought this during black Friday, so I got a decent deal, but I would not pay full price.Update 2/14/19My Flip4 fell on the floor at work today because the cheap little plastic piece that holds the paracord broke off. What a cheap piece of garbage. They could have made it out of metal molded into the rubber casing, but they took the easy way out . For something that's supposed to secure your speaker, JBL dropped the ball (and my speaker).Like I said initially...I'm glad I didn't pay full retail. Come on, JBL.

title: supports a wide range of music
body: Let me be clear from the beginning that this is not a long-term review. I bought this product yesterday. That being said, I have just ordered another one to connect with it. That's how impressed with it I am.I had been using a big Geneva tabletop unit with wonderful sound for years, but it had an unfortunate accident. I bought an Oontz angle 3 to fill in while I made up my mind about what to do next. (It quickly became clear that the Oontz angle 3 is not something I'm going to use for music, though it's's fine for use with my tablet for streaming television. It is very reliable, its bluetooth connectivity is great, but the sound is flat and thin. The Flip 4, on the other hand, has a much richer and fuller sound.  Does it have the sound of my old Geneva unit? Probably not, but I can connect two of these! I can hang it out on the front porch or from a light fixture in the hall by its handy strap. It has connected easily to both devices that I have tried it with so far. I play a wide range of music, from metal to solo vocal, from Indian classical to ambient electronic. The sound is good across ranges.It's clear from reviews of all devices that there are some lemons out there, so I'm hoping I got hold of a good unit and I'm happy to have Amazon behind me and my purchase.  If I have troubles, I'll update.

title: Love my Flip 4!!!
body: Ordered May of 20 & waited to review after it's been through some significant wear. Had many BT speakers and they've all taken a crap from a tumble or light water spray, even being rated rugged/water resistant.My opinion: won't get a better speaker for the money you pay! Been dropped many times, been down the river on a tubing trip (submerged multiple times), camping trips, & used almost daily.  Takes a lickin & keeps on tickin! Recharges at a decent rate (charged via wall at home, car, & solar battery pack while camping), plays for hours without losing sound integrity after battery is low, great sound/bass. Multiple speaker hookup (daisy chain) via BT which is awesome as a few friends also purchased these and we hook them up at outings and spread them out for an almost concert-like effect. Convenient to carry in purse, pack or duffle. Hand strap is a nice bonus as you can hang it just about anywhere. I plan on buying more of these. Would HIGHLY recommend - badass little speaker!!

title: I LOVE MY FLIP4
body: This is my 2nd JBL Flip4.  I love the ease of connectivity and that it has a microphone built in.  I can listen to music in the shower, take calls when I'm getting ready, use my Siri Voice Controls and everything.  The sound quality of this JBL is so good and full. title: Get your own!
body: Freaking love this thing and take it everywhere. I'm a musician, so I really appreciate the well balanced and detailed sound for what this is. Portability is great, calls actually work well on it, battery lasts an entire day by the pool (can confirm waterproof status as far as it won't kill it, but don't expect it to sound good in water). It also feels really, really solid. Like you could definitely knock someone out with it.It's bassy enough for me, I've got a JL ported 8" box in my truck if that tells you anything... I like balanced sound, not overpowering bass. I read entirely too many reviews of Bluetooth speakers in the range, and compared it to the UE Boom in best buy. Sound is somewhat subjective, but I found the UE sound to be a little thin in the midrange but had slightly more dynamic imaging in a room, but if you're using it outside I'm not sure that will show. The Flip 4 sounds fuller, warmer, while a bit more direct.If you understand that Beats headphones are garbage, you'll probably like this speaker. It's not a sub in the trunk, but you'll hear all the bass notes, though you won't necessarily feel them. It's an impressive product by JBL. I honestly wasn't a big JBL fan before this. Always thought their sound was Bose-ish...As in overrated and underwhelming. But it's very balanced, clear, and impressively powerful for its size.Sometimes I'll put this in the exterior bike-helmet pocket of my Camelbak M.U.L.E that has mesh openings to let sound through, and go for trail runs or long walks with my dog with tunes playing. Nice to be more aware of my surroundings (vs headphones) and that walkers can hear me coming or that cyclists approaching me can have a fair warning.If you're active like me, get it. And get your own, tired of everyone asking me to borrow it...

body: I was very pleased with this purchase in summer of 2019. I'm not an audiophile so I won't critique sound quality. It's good enough for me. I use this to watch YouTube videos through my phone because it's easier for my old ears to hear.I've had zero issues and have been using it almost daily for awhile. Until the past month. title: Great little speakers
body: This is a great speaker and I ordered 4 because of the ability to link up with each other with out wires (up to 4 speakers).My only "knock" would be that when they are paired up to each of the others, the battery power is used quite a bit. The bluetooth alone is an energy vacuum as it is.The 4 that I have, felt best by using 2 speakers at a time and charging the other two and rotating as needed. Great for a camp site/ backyard fire, a limo that didn't have a great sound system, pool side (water resistant - just dont celebrate it), getting ready time (waking up near head board, shower time to clothing to shaving),to small parties where you can stash the speakers in nooks out of the way and still have decent portable sound, barn parties up in rafters. Will not replace professional DJs and the equipment they provide.There are different size JBLs too, but i got these in the camo which I've only seen in black, red or blue at places like BestBuy, etc.You will need the nugget or a wall charger as mine only came with the USB cord. I have also made use of the lanyards as to hang them at ear level. If you place them in small rooms, just set them near the corners to get best sound resonance.Enjoy and happy listening.

title: Amazing and extremely handy to bring anywhere.
body: I decided to order the Certified Refurbished for 69.00 from RARTV.  I've always ordered refurbished electronics and had good luck.  This item is absolutely perfect.  Don't let the "plain box" thing stray you.  It's still very clearly custom made to fit the speaker perfectly,  it has cardboard holders on each end keeping the speaker suspended in the middle.  And a JBL sticker that fit's over the top of the box, not just a sticker pasted on, it's tailored to the box.  So you if don't care about the blah blah on-boxing and packaging, you get what you need.  The speaker doesn't have a mark on it and I wouldn't believe that it's not new, just repackaged due to a return our something.  That being said, I'm a child of the 80's where we had 5' tall speakers and massive amps.  I'm constantly amazed at how far things have come.  For it's size I'm astonished how well it sounds.  If you stick it in the corner of you counter top while cooking you'll get much more bass giving it corners to bounce off.  In a complete open area, the bass is surprisingly strong, but I would say it's highlights would be vocals, and clarity of all the stuff above the deep bass.  I can say this is for, the money, this is the most satisfying electronic's purchase I've made for a long time.  As soon as I heard it I immediately started thinking of more and more places I could bring good sounding music with me.  A definite thumbs up to JBL and RARTV for giving this quality for the money.

title: A noticeable upgrade from the Flip 3
body: My Flip 3's battery decided to visit Valhalla recently, and after a botched attempt at repairing that old workhorse failed (I accidentally sliced through the ribbon cable, oopsie!) I had to look for a replacement unit.  After a lot of searching, reading both professional and amateur reviews of the seemingly hundreds of Bluetooth speakers out there, I decided it'd be best to just get the Flip 4.  So far, I have not been disappointed with my purchase.Compared to the previous model, it seems the sound quality has been slightly improved on this version.  It's notably brighter than before, and the bass is ever so slightly less lumpy sounding.  It still won't fill a room up with thunderous boomy bass, but none of the speakers in this size category will.  Like the previous version, this thing feels like it's built like a tank, and may survive a drop or five on a hard surface without totally breaking.  All the buttons have a nice, tactile feel to them so you can easily adjust the volume or hit the play-pause-skip button without looking.  The buttons for power and linking two devices together are more recessed now, and a bit harder to hit, but this makes it easier to carry around without accidentally turning it off mid-song.I've had the speaker now for over a week and used it for approximately 30-45 minutes each day and so far it hasn't even dropped one "bar" on the battery light display, so I expect battery life to at least meet the quoted time on this site, if not exceed it.So far, I'm a happy camper.
